In order to enhance security within our classroom Zoom meetings, Rochester Community Schools teachers will be adjusting the settings on their meetings this week to require students to login to zoom with their district email addresses (@rcs-k12.us).

With this setting enabled, it will force all students to use the Sign In with Google button at https://zoom.us/signin. The only way a participant will be able to join your meeting is to connect with their school Google account. A message and video walking students through this new sign-in procedure can be found here: https://youtu.be/V4M6kvOPg40.

If you don't know your Google logon information, student logon information is available in ParentVUE and StudentVUE. Be sure to use the apps or Chrome browser.

RCS is pleased to offer alternative learning opportunities and career-training options to high-school students through our partnership with the Oakland Schools Technical Campuses (OSTC).

Students who are scheduled to take OSTC courses this semester should note the following important updates.

• OSTC courses will begin on Tuesday, Sept. 8, 2020. OSTC courses will not meet this week.

• Students registered for OSTC should have received a letter in the mail from OSTC describing class times and options.

• There is flexibility for students to attend the live online a.m. and p.m. lessons and to watch recorded video lessons. The goal is for students to become familiar with equipment, expectations and lab areas in preparation for eventual in-person learning, if possible. If students are unable to attend live online sessions, they may contact their instructors during office hours to make arrangements.

• OSTC teachers will be contacting students through the MiStar email system with specific course information. For MiStar email assistance, please call OSTC at 248-451-2700.

Families are invited to take advantage of the student wellness resources that have been compiled in a new website, developed specifically for the RCS community by our RCS teams. This valuable collection of tools provides crisis contacts, family activity ideas, parent resources, book recommendations, coping strategies, and contact information for the counselors and professionals in each school.

The social-emotional resource site can be accessed from the RCS webpage at www.rochester.k12.mi.us or you may go to: https://rcssocialemotionalresources.weebly.com/.

Our educators and support staff will use these tools throughout the school year to develop personal connections and foster students’ social-emotional awareness and sense of belonging. When educators aim to understand the experiences and backgrounds of their students, they can develop an appreciation for their students’ cultural identities and build authentic relationships. This creates a culture that promotes acceptance and trust, which can positively influence academic and social-emotional outcomes. #RCSYouMatter #RCSCountOnMe

Q: Will teachers be conducting remote and virtual classes from RCS school buildings or from other locations?

A: We are giving our teachers professional flexibility to teach in an environment that helps their students be successful. Some teachers want to be in their classrooms to familiarize students with learning areas like the book nook corner or the reading rug. Others need to be in classrooms to use our interactive flat panels for lessons. Still others have already created personal work spaces in their homes—some even hung green screens and set up cameras. We trust our caring and highly skilled professionals to provide engaging instruction in whichever location they choose. #RCSCountOnMe

Classes will begin on Tuesday, Sept. 1, for all students, which includes temporary remote learning and the RCS Virtual Campus. This date is a change from the original calendar to allow for staff planning and professional development on Aug. 31.

Sept. 1 will be a half day for all K-5 students and a full day for students in grades 6-12. Because school starts on a Tuesday, secondary students in grades 6-12 in remote learning will begin with their fourth-hour class. In the temporary remote learning schedule, Class periods 1, 2 and 3 meet on Monday and Thursday. Class periods 4, 5 and 6 meet on Tuesday and Friday. Students in the RCS Virtual Campus should follow their weekly schedule.

Secondary students will receive login information through their RCS Gmail accounts. Elementary students will receive instructions in the coming days.

As educators we have to listen and we have to be in tune with our students.”

To view the discussion, click this link: https://mrsgolidaylc.weebly.com/race-racism--privilege.html.

Thanks to brave, unsung heroes like Ms. Kalmus for reflecting and understanding to ensure all RCS students are heard, valued and respected. #RCSCountOnMe

Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer recently signed Executive Order No. 2020-164, which requires cloth face coverings in childcare facilities and summer camps, beginning today, Aug. 10.

The RCS Caring Steps Children's Center and School-Age Care (SAC) services have updated their policies.

Children ages 4 and older must wear a face covering during drop off and pick up times, and in hallways and common areas.

Children ages 12 and older are also required to wear a mask in classrooms.

Children should not wear a face covering if they are 2 years old or younger; cannot medically tolerate or independently remove a face covering; are outdoors practicing physical distancing; or during mealtimes, sleeping, swimming and some high-intensity activities.

Q: What if schools do not open on Aug. 31?
A: If the state or the district determines that schools are not ready to open at the start of the school year, the learning will still begin for RCS students!

Families who voluntarily enrolled in the RCS Virtual Campus will experience no changes to their full-time online curriculum.

Students who opted for in-person instruction will temporarily pivot to remote learning with their assigned teachers and class schedules. Remote learning is meant to be temporary, and will ensure continuity of learning, until we can return to school in person.

You can expect a rigorous, high-quality RCS education in all learning environments. #RCSpride #RCSCountOnMe

In an effort to reduce movement and contact within our middle schools and high schools, the task force team is strongly considering a new block schedule where secondary students attend three extended class periods per day.

This schedule reduces population in lunchrooms, extends passing time to allow for cleaning, and maintains the start and end time of the school day.

The team is also trying to link courses when possible to further reduce movement of students in the school.

More information can be found in the Learning Forward plan on the RCS website at: https://www.rochester.k12.mi.us/pages/58/district-info. #RCSCountOnMe

Update on Secondary Band and Choir Classes: Regardless of COVID-19 restrictions, the music staff is committed to teaching our students best practices in choral performance and wind/percussion instrument technique.

Direct instruction will take place in the classroom without singing/playing, and students will practice these skills safely at home. Staff is investigating different technology platforms to bring even greater meaning to home practice and to provide consistent feedback on student progress. While the secondary classes are performance based in their curricula, students will explore other musical concepts such as composing, recording, history, and theory.

The music staff realizes that students enroll in a performing arts class out of a desire to play an instrument or sing. In that spirit, our lessons will incorporate authentic performance as much and as safely as possible while exploring other strands of our Michigan Standards. Our performances will look much different than in the past but will still be meaningful to student development.

Q: Are remote learning and virtual learning the same thing?
A: No. They are two different learning options that are not interchangeable.

Remote learning only applies to students in in-person instruction, who may be required to pivot temporarily to online instruction due to public health conditions.

Virtual learning is a full-time online option that families may select as their preferred learning environment. It is not dependent on public health conditions and requires enrollment by Aug. 1 at www.rochester.k12.mi.us.

Q: Can my child wear a face shield instead of a mask?

A: According to the Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), face shields are not an alternative to masks or cloth face coverings. Respiratory droplets and aerosol can still enter around the sides and bottom of the face shield, so they are less protection than a mask. For those wearing a mask, face shields offer an excellent alternative to goggles for eye protection.

Masks and face coverings should: cover the nose and mouth, below the chin; fit snuggly but comfortably, against the sides of the face; be secured with ties or straps; and allow for breathing without restriction.

Click here for more Frequently Asked Questions: https://www.rochester.k12.mi.us/pages/58/district-info.

Q: What RCS cleaning protocols are used in school buildings?

A: RCS has reliable cleaning protocols that support safety and wellness and mitigate environmental health risks. All cleaning protocols and products meet industry standards and recommendations set by governmental health organizations. These rigorous standards apply to classrooms, offices, athletic facilities, food preparation areas, common areas and hard surfaces (including desks, light switches, and doors) in every building.

We have enhanced our cleaning capabilities by purchasing additional Clorox Total 360 and Emist electrostatic sprayers that distribute safe, commercial-grade, non-bleach cleaning solutions in hard-to-reach places. These sprayers, commonly used in schools and health care facilities, kill 99.9 percent of bacteria in five seconds. All learning environments will be deep-cleaned this summer and the custodial staff will have regular training throughout the school year.

Board of Education President Kristin Bull opened tonight's meeting with this statement from the board.

"The events of the past few weeks have shown us one thing: that those of us who have compassion and seek to understand one another are ready for a lasting change that allows equality to finally be the standard in our country. We stand in unity with our neighbors across the country being persecuted and harmed due to the color of their skin. We will not tolerate this any longer. We stand with all of our students who have peacefully demonstrated over the past two weeks in saying that Black Lives Matter. And while these issues often can be seen as political, they are not. They are human and just, and worth every minute of the attention they are getting … and so many more. As a district, as individuals -- as parents -- and as a board of education, we are committed to continuing this journey of understanding and equity until every single American is viewed as equal, worthy and valued." #RCSpride #RCSCountOnMe
